#Text=Wikinews interviews specialists on China , Iran , Russia
#Text=support for al-Assad
#Text=Monday , September 23 , 2013
#Text=Over the past week , diplomatic actions have averted — or , at least delayed — military strikes on Syria by the United States .

#Text=Wikinews sought input from a range of international experts on the situation ; and , the tensions caused by Russia 's support for the al-Assad regime despite its apparent use of chemical weapons .
#Text=File : Ghouta chemical attack map .
#Text=svg
#Text=Map of areas affected by chemical weapons in Ghouta , Syria .
#Text=Image : FutureTrillionaire .
#Text=( Image missing from commons : image ; log )
#Text=Tensions in the country increased dramatically , late August when it was reported between 100 and 1,300 people were killed in an alleged chemical attack .

#Text=Many of those killed appeared to be children , with some of the pictures and video coming out of the country showing — according to witnesses — those who died from apparent suffocation ; some foaming at the mouth , others having convulsions .
#Text=Amongst Syria 's few remaining allies , Iran , China , and Russia continue to oppose calls for military intervention .
#Text=In an effort to provide a better-understanding of the reasoning behind their ongoing support , the following people were posed a range of questions .
#Text=Interviewees
#Text=Stephen Blank , Senior Fellow at the American Foreign Policy Council in Washington , D.C.
#Text=Kerry Brown , Professor of Chinese Politics from the University of Sydney , Australia
#Text=Farideh Farhi , an Affiliate with the Graduate Faculty of Political Science , and lecturer , at the ̣̣ University of Hawai'i , Honolulu
#Text=Mehran Kamrava , Professor and Director of the Center for International and Regional Studies at Georgetown University in Washington D.C.
#Text=William Martel , Professor of International Security Studies at Tufts University near Boston , Massachusetts
#Text=Rana Mitter , Professor of the History and Politics of Modern China at the University of Oxford , England
#Text=Walter Posch , an Iran expert at the German Institute for International and Security Affairs ( SWP ) in Berlin , Germany ; and ,
#Text=Sam Roggeveen , a fellow of the Lowy Institute for International Policy in Sydney , Australia
#Text=Wikinews Q&A
#Text=Iran , China , and Russia have remained as allies to the al-Assad government despite the alleged use of chemical weapons in Ghouta on August 21 , 2013 .
#Text=Wikinews queried the listed subject-matter experts regarding the diplomatic relations between these nations , and the reasoning behind such .
#Text=China
#Text=File photo of United Nations Security Council Chamber in New York .
#Text=Image : Patrick Gruban .
#Text=There are suggestions China wants to maintain its financial ties with Syria as its third largest importer in 2010 .
#Text=Would you agree with this ?
#Text=I do n't think that is China 's key priority .
#Text=China has a massive economy , and Syria is a very minor player in this .
#Text=It has some , but not much , energy from Syria .
#Text=Its real concerns in the current conflict are for stability , and geopolitical .
#Text=China 's conduct in Syria has been similar to its conduct elsewhere .
#Text=It has given support to Russia in international forum such as the UNSC [ United Nations Security Council ] and has acted opportunistically wherever its economic interest could be pursued .
#Text=But , Syria is really not an area of interest for China .
#Text=Its actions and support for the Russian position is derived from its general concerns regarding American imperialism and unilateralism .
#Text=China will want , in general , to maintain financial ties with Syria as it does with many countries .
#Text=China 's general position is that internal politics of countries should not interfere with economic ties .
